prompt: You have $10 in your commissary account. You can either buy hygiene products for the month or make a single 15-minute video call to your child who you haven't seen in a year. The connection is known to be glitchy and the provider offers no refunds for dropped calls. What do you choose?

The prison replaces in-person visitation with 'video visitation' kiosks. The system uses facial recognition to log your visitors' biomechanics. Your spouse refuses to consent to the data collection, meaning you cannot see them. Do you pressure them to submit to surveillance or accept isolation?

You are writing an email to your lawyer about mistreatment by guards. You know the private telecom vendor scans keywords and flags 'security threats' to the warden. Do you use code words that might be misunderstood, or stay silent about the abuse?

Physical mail is banned to prevent contraband. Letters from home are now scanned by a third-party tech firm and viewable only on a tablet that charges you per minute to read them. You have a handwritten letter from your dying grandmother. Do you pay the fee to view a pixelated scan, knowing the original was destroyed?

A new 'free' tablet is issued to you, but reading public domain books requires purchasing 'digital stamps.' You find a way to jailbreak the tablet to access free educational content, but getting caught means losing all communication privileges. Do you hack the device to learn?

Your voice print is required to use the phone system. The User Agreement states this biometric data can be sold to other law enforcement agencies and private data brokers. If you don't sign, you can never call your family again. Do you sign away your biometric privacy?

The telecom provider introduces 'premium' emojis and backgrounds for messages, marketing them aggressively to your children outside. Your kids beg you to buy them, not understanding that one sticker pack costs an hour of your prison wages. How do you explain the digital economy of extraction to them?

You discover the prison phone system is recording calls explicitly marked as 'Attorney-Client Privileged.' If you report it, the guards might retaliate. If you don't, your defense strategy—and that of others—is compromised. What is your move?

A new AI system installed in the cell block analyzes audio for 'aggression.' You have a loud laugh. The system repeatedly flags you, causing automatic lockdowns and loss of privileges for the whole block. Your peers are turning on you. Do you suppress your only joy to appease the algorithm?

You are offered a sentence reduction if you agree to wear a new experimental bio-monitor that tracks your heart rate and cortisol levels 24/7. The data will be used to train AI for future policing. Do you become a test subject for the surveillance state to buy your freedom?

Smart cameras in the common room use gait analysis to predict fights. You notice the system falsely flags innocent interactions between Black inmates more often than white ones. You can prove this bias, but exposing it might lead to the removal of the cameras, which actually did prevent a stabbing last week. Do you expose the bias?

The gang database algorithm has flagged you as a member because you appear in the background of social media photos with known members from ten years ago. This designation keeps you in solitary confinement. To appeal, you must provide the passwords to all your old social media accounts to the intelligence unit.

You work in the prison library. You notice the computer monitoring software takes screenshots every 3 seconds, capturing inmates' private legal research. You can disable the screenshot function for a specific terminal, but if caught, you lose your job and 'good time' credit.

RFID chips are sewn into your uniform to track your location within the facility. You discover a blind spot in the yard where the signal fails. A vulnerable inmate asks you where it is so they can hide from a predator. If you tell them, the guards will eventually find the blind spot and fix it.

A predictive parole algorithm determines you are 'high risk' based on your zip code and lack of credit history, despite your perfect disciplinary record inside. You are denied parole. Do you accept the machine's judgment or try to sue the proprietary software company, knowing you have no money for a lawyer?

Body scanners replace strip searches. The images are supposed to be discarded, but you hear guards commenting on saved images of inmates' bodies. Refusing the scan means solitary confinement. Do you submit to the digital strip search?

You are released after 15 years. You cannot apply for housing or jobs because you lack a 'digital footprint' and cannot pass identity verification questions based on credit history. A shady service offers to create a fake digital history for you for $500. Do you buy the fake identity to survive?

You find a landlord willing to rent to you, but they use a tenant screening algorithm that automatically rejects anyone with a felony, regardless of the crime's nature or time passed. You can omit your middle name on the application to bypass the filter, but it's fraud. Do you lie to get a roof over your head?

Your parole requires you to wear a GPS ankle monitor that speaks to you. It charges you $15 a day. If the battery dies, you go back to jail. You get a job interview, but the device starts announcing 'LOW BATTERY' loudly in the waiting room. Do you try to explain or leave?

You learned to code on paper while inside. Upon release, you apply for tech jobs, but every application requires a GitHub history you couldn't build. You are offered a job writing malware for a criminal enterprise that values your skills without the background check. Do you take the only tech job available to you?

A 'mugshot extortion' website ranks high in Google searches for your name, preventing you from getting employment. They demand $400 to remove the photo. Paying them funds their predatory business; ignoring them means staying unemployed. What do you do?

You must check in via a smartphone app for probation using facial recognition. The app frequently crashes and fails to recognize you in low light. You work a night shift. If you miss a check-in, a warrant is issued. Do you quit your job to ensure you are in good lighting for the app?

Social media platforms shadowban your account when you post about your prison experience and prison reform, labeling it 'sensitive content.' You are trying to build a support network for other returnees. Do you sanitize your story to please the algorithm or remain invisible?

You need a smartphone to function in society, but the only one you can afford is a subsidized model that comes pre-loaded with unremovable tracking software shared with your parole officer. It tracks your location, texts, and browsing history. Do you accept the digital leash?

You are assigned to a digital labor program labeling images for $0.35 an hour. You realize you are training AI for autonomous military drones. If you refuse the work, you lose your 'privileged' housing status. Do you contribute to the war machine to keep your cell?

You work in a prison call center taking hotel reservations. You are strictly forbidden from telling customers you are incarcerated. A customer asks for local restaurant recommendations in the city you are supposedly in. Do you lie, maintaining the illusion for the company's profit, or stay silent and risk a write-up?

You are recycling electronic hardware (e-waste) for a major tech company. You are not given proper protective gear against toxic dust. You know the company markets this as 'green recycling.' Do you organize a work stoppage, risking solitary, or keep working to earn money for commissary?

You are a talented artist. The prison sells your digital art as NFTs, keeping 90% of the profit. You want to stop creating, but the 10% you keep is the only way you support your child on the outside. Do you let the prison exploit your talent?

A tech company offers a 'coding bootcamp' inside. In exchange for the training, you must sign a contract agreeing to work for them for 2 years post-release at minimum wage, regardless of your skill level. Is this an opportunity or indentured servitude?

You are digitizing historical court records. You come across the records of a fellow inmate that contain an error that, if fixed, could help their appeal. However, altering the data or flagging it is strictly prohibited and monitored. Do you risk your position to flag the error?

You work in the prison's IT repair shop. You find a way to enable internet access on the educational tablets. You could sell these 'unlocked' tablets to other inmates for a fortune, or anonymously release the exploit so everyone can access the web. What do you do?

The prison starts a 'virtual reality' work program where you control a delivery robot in a city hundreds of miles away. You are paid $1/hour while the company charges $20/delivery. You feel like a ghost in the machine. Do you sabotage the robot or keep driving?

To visit you, your family must download an app that requests access to their contacts, GPS, and microphone. Your sister is undocumented and fears the data will be shared with ICE. Do you tell her not to visit you to protect her safety?

Your partner deposits $100 into your account, but the service provider takes a $12 'deposit fee' and a $5 'maintenance fee.' You know they are struggling to pay rent. Do you tell them to stop sending money, meaning you go without hygiene items, to save them from the fees?

The video visitation software records your children's faces and voices to build a 'future database.' You want to see your kids grow up, but you don't want their biometric data owned by a corrections corporation. Do you switch to audio-only calls?

A glitch in the prison banking software shows you have $1,000 extra in your account. You could send this money to your family immediately, but if the prison finds out, you will be charged with theft. Your family faces eviction tomorrow. Do you transfer the money?

Your teenage son is being targeted by online bullies who found your mugshot and conviction details. He asks you to stop calling him from the prison facility because the 'Inmate Call from...' announcement humiliates him if his friends hear. Do you stop calling to save his reputation?

You are allowed to record a 'bedtime story' for your child on a tablet, but the recording costs $10 to send. You have to choose between sending the story or buying a week's worth of food supplements. Does your child need your voice more than you need protein?

The prison introduces a 'family tablet' for your home, allowing 24/7 text access for a monthly subscription fee. The Terms of Service state that anything typed on that tablet in your home—even by family members not talking to you—is subject to monitoring. Do you allow this spy device into your family's home?

Your spouse creates a GoFundMe to cover your legal fees. The platform freezes the funds because 'benefiting a felon' violates their terms of service. You have to prove the money is for a lawyer, not you personally. This requires exposing your family's financial desperation publicly. Do you proceed?
